You can't authorize ingress from an EC2 security group in one AWS Region to an Amazon RDS DB instance in another. You can't authorize ingress from a VPC security group in one VPC to an Amazon RDS DB instance in another.
Admin can manage DB security group controls access to EC2-Classic DB instances that are not in a VPC.
Permission controlled by AWS > RDS > Subnet Group Management
Deletion of snapshots is limited to Admins even though Operators can create them.
Admins can delete automated backups based on the source instance's DbiResourceId value or the restorable instance's resource ID.
Deletion of snapshots is limited to Admins even though Operators can create them.
Permission controlled by AWS > RDS > Subnet Group Management
Admins can set the capacity of an Aurora Serverless DB cluster to a specific value.
Admins can modify the properties of an endpoint in an Amazon Aurora DB cluster.
Allows for cross-account access.
Can update a manual DB snapshot's engine version. Currently only supports MySQL.
Allows for cross-account access.

Admin can create backup of there database and store it in s3.

dbClusterActive.title: Active
dbClusterActive.description:
Take an action when an AWS RDS db cluster is not active based on the
`AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Active > *` policies.

The Active control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated compliance
environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms that are difficult
and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings automated, well-defined
control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.

Note the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

dbClusterApproved.title: Approved
dbClusterApproved.description:
Take an action when an AWS RDS db cluster is not approved based on `AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Approved > * policies`.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

For any enforcement actions that specify `if new`, e.g., `Enforce: Delete unapproved if new`, this control will only take the enforcement actions for resources created within the last 60 minutes.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

precheck.reason: CMDB control is in TBD state

dbClusterCmdb.title: CMDB
dbClusterCmdb.description:
Record and synchronize details for the AWS RDS db cluster into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

CMDB controls also use the Regions policy associated with the resource. If region is not in `AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Regions` policy, the CMDB control will delete the resource from the CMDB. (**Note**: Setting CMDB to Skip will also pause these changes.)

dbClusterConfigured.title: Configured
dbClusterConfigured.description:
Maintain AWS > RDS > DB Cluster configuration

**Note**: If the resource is managed by another stack, then the Skip/Check/Enforce values here are ignored
and inherit from the stack that owns it

dbClusterDiscovery.title: Discovery
dbClusterDiscovery.description:
Discover all AWS RDS db cluster resources and add them to the CMDB.

The [Discovery](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/discovery) control is responsible for finding resources of a specific type. It periodically searches for new resources and saves them to the CMDB. Once discovered, resources are then responsible for tracking changes to themselves through the [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control.

Note that Discovery and CMDB controls also use the Regions policy associated with the resource. If the region is not in `AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Regions` policy, the CMDB control will delete the resource from the CMDB.

dbClusterSchedule.title: Schedule
dbClusterSchedule.description:
Set a schedule for starting and stopping an AWS RDS db cluster.

**Note** If both "Schedule" and "Schedule Tag" are set to enforce and the
db cluster has a turbot_custom_schedule tag, then the schedule specified by
the tag will be in effect.

precheck.reason: CMDB control is in TBD state

dbClusterTags.title: Tags
dbClusterTags.description:
Take an action when an AWS RDS db cluster tags is not updated based on the `AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Tags > * policies`.

If the resource is not updated with the tags defined in `AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Tags > Template`, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.

dbClusterUsage.title: Usage
dbClusterUsage.description:
The Usage control determines whether the number of AWS RDS db cluster resources exceeds the configured usage limit for this region.

You can configure the behavior of this control with the  `AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Usage` policy, and set the limit with the `AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Usage > Limit` policy.

dbClusterSnapshotManualTrustedAccess.title: Trusted Access
dbClusterSnapshotManualTrustedAccess.description:
Manage trusted access for AWS RDS DB Cluster Snapshot [Manual]s.

AWS allows RDS DB Cluster Snapshot [Manual]s to be shared with specific AWS accounts.
This control allows you to configure whether such sharing is allowed, and to which accounts.

If set to `Enforce`, access to non-trusted accounts will be removed.

The Usage control determines whether the number of AWS RDS db parameter group resources exceeds the configured usage limit for this region.

You can configure the behavior of this control with the  `AWS > RDS > DB Parameter Group > Usage` policy, and set the limit with the `AWS > RDS > DB Parameter Group > Usage > Limit` policy.

dbSnapshotManualActive.title: Active
dbSnapshotManualActive.description:
Take an action when an AWS RDS db snapshot [manual] is not active based on the
`AWS > RDS > DB Snapshot [Manual] > Active > *` policies.

The Active control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated compliance
environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms that are difficult
and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings automated, well-defined
control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > RDS > DB Snapshot [Manual] > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.

Note the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

dbSnapshotManualApproved.title: Approved
dbSnapshotManualApproved.description:
Take an action when an AWS RDS db snapshot [manual] is not approved based on `AWS > RDS > DB Snapshot [Manual] > Approved > * policies`.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

For any enforcement actions that specify `if new`, e.g., `Enforce: Delete unapproved if new`, this control will only take the enforcement actions for resources created within the last 60 minutes.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

precheck.reason: CMDB control is in TBD state

dbSnapshotManualCmdb.title: CMDB
dbSnapshotManualCmdb.description:
Record and synchronize details for the AWS RDS db snapshot [manual] into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

CMDB controls also use the Regions policy associated with the resource. If region is not in `AWS > RDS > DB Snapshot [Manual] > Regions` policy, the CMDB control will delete the resource from the CMDB. (**Note**: Setting CMDB to Skip will also pause these changes.)

dbSnapshotManualConfigured.title: Configured
dbSnapshotManualConfigured.description:
Maintain AWS > RDS > DB Snapshot [Manual] configuration

**Note**: If the resource is managed by another stack, then the Skip/Check/Enforce values here are ignored
and inherit from the stack that owns it

dbSnapshotManualDiscovery.title: Discovery
dbSnapshotManualDiscovery.description:
Discover all AWS RDS db snapshot [manual] resources and add them to the CMDB.

The [Discovery](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/discovery) control is responsible for finding resources of a specific type. It periodically searches for new resources and saves them to the CMDB. Once discovered, resources are then responsible for tracking changes to themselves through the [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control.

Note that Discovery and CMDB controls also use the Regions policy associated with the resource. If the region is not in `AWS > RDS > DB Snapshot [Manual] > Regions` policy, the CMDB control will delete the resource from the CMDB.

dbSnapshotManualTags.title: Tags
dbSnapshotManualTags.description:
Take an action when an AWS RDS db snapshot [manual] tags is not updated based on the `AWS > RDS > DB Snapshot [Manual] > Tags > * policies`.

If the resource is not updated with the tags defined in `AWS > RDS > DB Snapshot [Manual] > Tags > Template`, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.

dbSnapshotManualTrustedAccess.title: Trusted Access
dbSnapshotManualTrustedAccess.description:
Manage trusted access for AWS RDS DB Snapshot [Manual]s.

AWS allows RDS DB Snapshot [Manual]s to be shared with specific AWS accounts.
This control allows you to configure whether such sharing is allowed, and to which accounts.

If set to `Enforce`, access to non-trusted accounts will be removed.

rdsStack.title: Stack
rdsStack.description:
Configure a custom stack on AWS, per the custom `Stack > Source`.

A Turbot `Stack` is a set of resources configured by Turbot, as specified
via Terraform source.  Stacks are responsible for the creation and deletion
of multiple resources. Once created, stack resources are responsible for
configuring themselves from the stack source via their `Configured` control.

dbClusterActive.title: Active
dbClusterActive.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS RDS db cluster, based on the `AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Active > *` policies.

The control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not,
has the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated

that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Active > *`), raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement
action. Each Active sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive
or skipped. Generally, if the resource appears to be Active for any reason
it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved for any reason it will be considered
Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Enforce: Snapshot and delete inactive with 1 day warning
Enforce: Snapshot and delete inactive with 3 days warning
Enforce: Snapshot and delete inactive with 7 days warning
Enforce: Snapshot and delete inactive with 14 days warning
Enforce: Snapshot and delete inactive with 30 days warning
Enforce: Snapshot and delete inactive with 60 days warning
Enforce: Snapshot and delete inactive with 90 days warning
Enforce: Snapshot and delete inactive with 180 days warning
Enforce: Snapshot and delete inactive with 365 days warning

enum: Force active if last modified <= 1 day
Force active if last modified <= 3 days

dbClusterActiveBudget.title: Budget
dbClusterActiveBudget.description:
The impact of the budget state on the active control. This policy allows you to force
dbClusters to inactive based on the current budget state, as reflected in
`AWS > Account > Budget > State`

The Active control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated compliance
environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms that are difficult
and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings automated, well-defined
control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the

if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Force inactive if Budget > State is Over or higher
Force inactive if Budget > State is Critical or higher
Force inactive if Budget > State is Shutdown

dbClusterApproved.title: Approved
dbClusterApproved.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS RDS db cluster is not approved based on `AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Approved > *` policies.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

For any enforcement actions that specify `if new`, e.g., `Enforce: Delete unapproved if new`, this control will only take the enforcement actions for resources created within the last 60 minutes.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

enum: Enforce: Snapshot and delete unapproved if new

dbClusterApprovedRegions.title: Regions
dbClusterApprovedRegions.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS RDS db clusters are approved for use.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and '?' wildcard characters.

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS RDS db cluster is created in a region that is not in the approved list, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.
dbClusterApprovedRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

dbClusterApprovedUsage.title: Usage
dbClusterApprovedUsage.description:
Determine whether the AWS RDS db cluster is allowed to exist.

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS RDS db cluster is not approved, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

dbClusterApprovedBudget.title: Budget
dbClusterApprovedBudget.description:
The policy allows you to set db clusters to unapproved based on the current budget state, as reflected in `AWS > Account > Budget > State`

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS RDS db cluster is not matched by the approved list, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

enum: Unapproved if Budget > State is Over or higher
Unapproved if Budget > State is Critical or higher
Unapproved if Budget > State is Shutdown
example: Unapproved if Budget > State is Shutdown

dbClusterCmdb.title: CMDB
dbClusterCmdb.description:
Configure whether to record and synchronize details for the AWS RDS db cluster into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.
All policies and controls in Turbot are based around the resource, so usually the CMDB policy is set to **"Enforce: Enabled"**.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

CMDB controls also use the Regions policy associated with the resource. If region is not in `AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Regions` policy, the CMDB control will delete the resource from the CMDB.

(**Note**: Setting CMDB to **"Skip"** will also pause these changes.)

dbClusterConfigured.title: Configured
dbClusterConfigured.description:
Determine how to configure this resource.

**Note**: If the resource is managed by another stack, then the Skip/Check/Enforce values here are ignored
and inherit from the stack that owns it

enum: Check: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)
Enforce: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)

dbClusterConfiguredSource.title: Source
dbClusterConfiguredSource.description: A HCL or JSON format Terraform configuration source used to configure this resource

dbClusterConfiguredPrecedence.title: Claim Precedence
dbClusterConfiguredPrecedence.description:
An ordered list of who is allowed to claim a resource.
A stack cannot claim a resource if it is already claimed by another
stack at a higher level of precedence.
dbClusterConfiguredPrecedence.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultPrecedence | length == 0 %}[]{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultPrecedence %}- '{{ item }}'{% endfor %}{% endif %}

dbClusterRegions.title: Regions
dbClusterRegions.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS RDS db clusters are supported for use.

Any db clusters in a region not listed here will not be recorded in CMDB.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and
'?' wildcard characters.
dbClusterRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions.value | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

dbClusterSchedule.title: Schedule
dbClusterSchedule.description:
Set a schedule for starting and stopping an AWS RDS db cluster.

**Note** If both "Schedule" and "Schedule Tag" are set to enforce and the
db cluster has a turbot_custom_schedule tag, then the schedule specified by
the tag will be in effect.

enum: Enforce: Extended business hours (7:00am - 11:00pm on weekdays)
Enforce: Stop for night (stop at 10:00pm every day)
Enforce: Stop for weekend (stop at 10:00pm on Friday)

dbClusterScheduleTag.title: Schedule Tag
dbClusterScheduleTag.description:
Allow setting a schedule for starting and stopping an RDS db cluster via the
turbot_custom_schedule tag. If the schedule is invalid, no actions will be
taken against the dbCluster.

**Note** If both "Schedule" and "Schedule Tag" are set to enforce and the
db cluster has a turbot_custom_schedule, then the schedule specified by the
tag will be in effect.

dbClusterTags.title: Tags
dbClusterTags.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS RDS db cluster tags are not updated based on the `AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Tags > *` policies.

The control ensure AWS RDS db cluster tags include tags defined in `AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Tags > Template`.

Tags not defined in DB Cluster Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.

dbClusterTagsTemplate.title: Template
dbClusterTagsTemplate.description:
The template is used to generate the keys and values for AWS RDS db cluster.

Tags not defined in DB Cluster Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.
dbClusterTagsTemplate.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultTags.value | length == 0 %} [] {%- elif $.defaultTags.value != undefined %}{{ $.defaultTags.value | dump | safe }}{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultTags.value %}- {{ item }}{% endfor %}{% endif %}

dbClusterUsage.title: Usage
dbClusterUsage.description:
Configure the number of AWS RDS db clusters that can be used for this region and the current consumption against the limit.

You can configure the behavior of the control with this  `AWS > RDS > DB Cluster > Usage` policy.

dbClusterUsageLimit.title: Limit
dbClusterUsageLimit.description: Maximum number of items that can be created for this region.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

dbClusterParameterGroupCmdb.title: CMDB

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.
All policies and controls in Turbot are based around the resource, so usually the CMDB policy is set to **"Enforce: Enabled"**.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

CMDB controls also use the Regions policy associated with the resource. If region is not in `AWS > RDS > DB Cluster Parameter Group > Regions` policy, the CMDB control will delete the resource from the CMDB.

(**Note**: Setting CMDB to **"Skip"** will also pause these changes.)

dbInstanceApprovedInstanceClasses.description:
A list of instance classes that the AWS RDS db instance is approved to use.

The expected format is an array of instance classes. You may use the `*` and `?` wildcard characters (and [more](https://github.com/micromatch/micromatch#matching-features)).

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS RDS db instance is not matched by the approved list, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > RDS > DB Instance > Approved` policy.

```
example:
  db.t2.large
```

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

dbInstanceApprovedDatabaseEngines.title: Database Engines
dbInstanceApprovedDatabaseEngines.description:
A list of database engines that the AWS RDS db instance is approved to use.

The expected format is an array of database engines. You may use the `*` and `?` wildcard characters (and [more](https://github.com/micromatch/micromatch#matching-features)).

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS RDS db instance is not matched by the approved list, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > RDS > DB Instance > Approved` policy.

```
example:
  postgres
```

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

dbInstanceEncryptionAtRest.title: Encryption at Rest
dbInstanceEncryptionAtRest.description:
Define the Encryption at Rest settings required for `AWS > RDS > DB Instance`.

Encryption at Rest refers specifically to the encryption of data when written
to an underlying storage system. This control determines whether the resource
is encrypted at rest, and sets encryption to your desired level.

The [Encryption at Rest](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/encryption-at-rest)
control compares the encryption settings against the encryption policies for the resource
(`AWS > RDS > DB Instance > Encryption at Rest  > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action

enum: Encryption at Rest > Customer Managed Key

dbInstanceEncryptionAtRestCustomerManage.title: Customer Managed Key
dbInstanceEncryptionAtRestCustomerManage.description:
Define the KMS key ID for encryption at rest.

Encryption at Rest refers specifically to the encryption of data when written
to an underlying storage system. This control determines whether the resource
is encrypted at rest, and sets encryption to your desired level.

The [Encryption at Rest](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/encryption-at-rest)
control compares the encryption settings against the encryption policies for the resource
(`AWS > RDS > DB Instance > Encryption at Rest  > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action

Please make sure the key defined in the template has required permissions.

```
example:
  alias/aws/ebs
  ddc06e04-ce5f-4995-c758-c2b6c510e8fd
  arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/ddc06e04-ce5f-4995-c758-c2b6c510e8fd
  arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:alias/aws/ebs
```

dbInstanceCmdb.title: CMDB
dbInstanceCmdb.description:
Configure whether to record and synchronize details for the AWS RDS db instance into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.
All policies and controls in Turbot are based around the resource, so usually the CMDB policy is set to **"Enforce: Enabled"**.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

CMDB controls also use the Regions policy associated with the resource. If region is not in `AWS > RDS > DB Instance > Regions` policy, the CMDB control will delete the resource from the CMDB.

(**Note**: Setting CMDB to **"Skip"** will also pause these changes.)

dbInstanceConfigured.title: Configured
dbInstanceConfigured.description:
Determine how to configure this resource.

**Note**: If the resource is managed by another stack, then the Skip/Check/Enforce values here are ignored
and inherit from the stack that owns it

enum: Check: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)
Enforce: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)

dbInstanceConfiguredSource.title: Source
dbInstanceConfiguredSource.description: A HCL or JSON format Terraform configuration source used to configure this resource

dbInstanceConfiguredPrecedence.title: Claim Precedence
dbInstanceConfiguredPrecedence.description:
An ordered list of who is allowed to claim a resource.
A stack cannot claim a resource if it is already claimed by another
stack at a higher level of precedence.
dbInstanceConfiguredPrecedence.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultPrecedence | length == 0 %}[]{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultPrecedence %}- '{{ item }}'{% endfor %}{% endif %}

dbInstanceParameterGroup.title: Parameter Group
dbInstanceParameterGroup.description:
Determine whether to check or enforce a specific Parameter Group for this DB Instance.

Use the `Parameter Group > Name` sub-policy to set which Parameter Group to configure for this instance.

enum: Check: Set to Parameter Group > Name
Enforce: Set to Parameter Group > Name
Enforce: Set to Parameter Group > Name (Create if missing)
example: Check: Set to Parameter Group > Name

dbInstanceParameterGroupName.title: Name
dbInstanceParameterGroupName.description:
The name of a DB Parameter Group for this DB Instance.

If the parent `Parameter Group` policy is set to `Enforce: Set to Parameter Group > Name (Create if missing)` a new parameter group with this name will be created if it does not already exist.

dbInstancePubliclyAccessible.title: Publicly Accessible
dbInstancePubliclyAccessible.description: Ensure the RDS instance is not publicly accessible.

enum: Check: DB Instance is not publicly accessible
Enforce: DB Instance is not publicly accessible

dbInstanceRegions.title: Regions
dbInstanceRegions.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS RDS db instances are supported for use.

Any db instances in a region not listed here will not be recorded in CMDB.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and
'?' wildcard characters.
dbInstanceRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions.value | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

instanceSchedule.title: Schedule
instanceSchedule.description:
Set a schedule for starting and stopping an AWS RDS db instance.

**Note** If both "Schedule" and "Schedule Tag" are set to enforce and the
the tag will be in effect.

enum: Enforce: Extended business hours (7:00am - 11:00pm on weekdays)
Enforce: Stop for night (stop at 10:00pm every day)
Enforce: Stop for weekend (stop at 10:00pm on Friday)

instanceScheduleTag.title: Schedule Tag
instanceScheduleTag.description:
Allow setting a schedule for starting and stopping an RDS db instance via the
turbot_custom_schedule tag. If the schedule is invalid, no actions will be
taken against the dbInstance.

**Note** If both "Schedule" and "Schedule Tag" are set to enforce and the
db instance has a turbot_custom_schedule, then the schedule specified by the
tag will be in effect.

dbInstanceTags.title: Tags
dbInstanceTags.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS RDS db instance tags are not updated based on the `AWS > RDS > DB Instance > Tags > *` policies.

The control ensure AWS RDS db instance tags include tags defined in `AWS > RDS > DB Instance > Tags > Template`.

Tags not defined in DB Instance Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.

dbInstanceTagsTemplate.title: Template
dbInstanceTagsTemplate.description:
The template is used to generate the keys and values for AWS RDS db instance.

Tags not defined in DB Instance Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.
dbInstanceTagsTemplate.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultTags.value | length == 0 %} [] {%- elif $.defaultTags.value != undefined %}{{ $.defaultTags.value | dump | safe }}{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultTags.value %}- {{ item }}{% endfor %}{% endif %}

dbInstanceUsage.title: Usage
dbInstanceUsage.description:
Configure the number of AWS RDS db instances that can be used for this region and the current consumption against the limit.

You can configure the behavior of the control with this  `AWS > RDS > DB Instance > Usage` policy.

dbInstanceUsageLimit.title: Limit
dbInstanceUsageLimit.description: Maximum number of items that can be created for this region.

dbParameterGroupActive.title: Active
dbParameterGroupActive.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS RDS db parameter group, based on the `AWS > RDS > DB Parameter Group > Active > *` policies.

The control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not,
has the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > RDS > DB Parameter Group > Active > *`), raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement
action. Each Active sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive
or skipped. Generally, if the resource appears to be Active for any reason
it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved for any reason it will be considered
Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Enforce: Delete inactive with 1 day warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 3 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 7 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 14 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 30 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 60 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 90 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 180 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 365 days warning

dbParameterGroupActiveLastModified.title: Last Modified
dbParameterGroupActiveLastModified.description:
The number of days since the AWS RDS db parameter group
was last modified before it is considered inactive.

The [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)
control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > RDS > DB Parameter Group > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Force active if last modified <= 1 day
Force active if last modified <= 3 days
Force active if last modified <= 7 days
Force active if last modified <= 14 days
Force active if last modified <= 30 days
Force active if last modified <= 60 days
Force active if last modified <= 90 days
Force active if last modified <= 180 days
Force active if last modified <= 365 days

dbParameterGroupApproved.title: Approved
dbParameterGroupApproved.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS RDS db parameter group is not approved based on `AWS > RDS > DB Parameter Group > Approved > *` policies.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

For any enforcement actions that specify `if new`, e.g., `Enforce: Delete unapproved if new`, this control will only take the enforcement actions for resources created within the last 60 minutes.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

dbParameterGroupApprovedRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions %}- '{{ item }}'

dbSnapshotManualConfiguredSource.description: A HCL or JSON format Terraform configuration source used to configure this resource

dbSnapshotManualConfiguredPrecedence.title: Claim Precedence
dbSnapshotManualConfiguredPrecedence.description:

stack at a higher level of precedence.
dbSnapshotManualConfiguredPrecedence.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultPrecedence | length == 0 %}[]{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultPrecedence %}- '{{ item }}'{% endfor %}{% endif %}

dbSnapshotManualRegions.title: Regions
dbSnapshotManualRegions.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS RDS db snapshot [manual]s are supported for use.

Any db snapshot [manual]s in a region not listed here will not be recorded in CMDB.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and

dbSnapshotManualRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions.value | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

dbSnapshotManualTags.title: Tags
dbSnapshotManualTags.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS RDS db snapshot [manual] tags are not updated based on the `AWS > RDS > DB Snapshot [Manual] > Tags > *` policies.

The control ensure AWS RDS db snapshot [manual] tags include tags defined in `AWS > RDS > DB Snapshot [Manual] > Tags > Template`.

Tags not defined in DB Snapshot [Manual] Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.

dbSnapshotManualTagsTemplate.title: Template
dbSnapshotManualTagsTemplate.description:
The template is used to generate the keys and values for AWS RDS db snapshot [manual].

dbSnapshotManualTagsTemplate.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultTags.value | length == 0 %} [] {%- elif $.defaultTags.value != undefined %}{{ $.defaultTags.value | dump | safe }}{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultTags.value %}- {{ item }}{% endfor %}{% endif %}

dbSnapshotManualTrustedAccess.title: Trusted Access
dbSnapshotManualTrustedAccess.description:
Manage trusted access for AWS RDS DB Snapshot [Manual]s.

AWS allows RDS DB Snapshot [Manual]s to be shared with specific AWS accounts.
This policy allows you to configure whether such sharing is allowed, and to which accounts.

If set to `Enforce`, access to non-trusted accounts will be removed.

{% if $.accounts | length == 0 %}[]{% endif %}{% for item in $.accounts %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

dbSnapshotManualUsageLimit.title: Limit
dbSnapshotManualUsageLimit.description: Maximum number of items that can be created for this region.

optionGroupActive.title: Active
optionGroupActive.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS RDS option group, based on the `AWS > RDS > Option Group > Active > *` policies.

The control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not,
has the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > RDS > Option Group > Active > *`), raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement
action. Each Active sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive
or skipped. Generally, if the resource appears to be Active for any reason
it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved for any reason it will be considered
Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Enforce: Delete inactive with 1 day warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 3 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 7 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 14 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 30 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 60 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 90 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 180 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 365 days warning

optionGroupActiveLastModified.title: Last Modified
optionGroupActiveLastModified.description:
The number of days since the AWS RDS option group
was last modified before it is considered inactive.

The [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)
control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > RDS > Option Group > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Force active if last modified <= 1 day
Force active if last modified <= 3 days
Force active if last modified <= 7 days
Force active if last modified <= 14 days
Force active if last modified <= 30 days
Force active if last modified <= 60 days
Force active if last modified <= 90 days
Force active if last modified <= 180 days
Force active if last modified <= 365 days

optionGroupActiveAge.title: Age
optionGroupActiveAge.description:
The age after which the AWS RDS option group
is no longer considered active. If a create time is unavailable, the time Turbot discovered the resource is used.

The [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)
control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the

**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

optionGroupApproved.title: Approved
optionGroupApproved.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS RDS option group is not approved based on `AWS > RDS > Option Group > Approved > *` policies.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

For any enforcement actions that specify `if new`, e.g., `Enforce: Delete unapproved if new`, this control will only take the enforcement actions for resources created within the last 60 minutes.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

optionGroupApprovedRegions.title: Regions
optionGroupApprovedRegions.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS RDS option groups are approved for use.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and '?' wildcard characters.

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS RDS option group is created in a region that is not in the approved list, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > RDS > Option Group > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.
optionGroupApprovedRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

optionGroupApprovedUsage.title: Usage
optionGroupApprovedUsage.description:
Determine whether the AWS RDS option group is allowed to exist.

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS RDS option group is not approved, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > RDS > Option Group > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

optionGroupCmdb.title: CMDB
optionGroupCmdb.description:
Configure whether to record and synchronize details for the AWS RDS option group into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.
All policies and controls in Turbot are based around the resource, so usually the CMDB policy is set to **"Enforce: Enabled"**.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

CMDB controls also use the Regions policy associated with the resource. If region is not in `AWS > RDS > Option Group > Regions` policy, the CMDB control will delete the resource from the CMDB.

(**Note**: Setting CMDB to **"Skip"** will also pause these changes.)

optionGroupUsageLimit.title: Limit
optionGroupUsageLimit.description: Maximum number of items that can be created for this region.

rdsCustomEventPatterns.title: RDS
rdsCustomEventPatterns.description:
The CloudWatch Events event pattern used by the AWS RDS module to specify
which events to forward to the Turbot Event Handlers.

rdsApiEnabled.title: API Enabled
rdsApiEnabled.description:
Configure whether the AWS RDS API is enabled.

**Note:** Disabling the service disables the API for ALL users
and roles, and Turbot will have no access to the API.

rdsPermissions.title: Permissions
rdsPermissions.description:
Configure whether permissions policies are in effect for AWS RDS.
This setting does not affect account level permissions (AWS/Admin, AWS/Owner, etc).

**Note:** The behavior of this policy depends on the value of `AWS > Permissions`."

enum: Enabled if AWS > RDS > Enabled & AWS > RDS > API Enabled
schema.default: Enabled if AWS > RDS > Enabled & AWS > RDS > API Enabled

rdsPermissionsLockdownApiBoundary.title: API Boundary
rdsPermissionsLockdownApiBoundary.description:
Configure whether the AWS RDS API is enabled for
all users and roles in turbot-managed boundary policies.

**Note:** Disabling the service disables the API for ALL users
and roles, and Turbot will have no access to the API.

enum: Enabled if AWS > RDS > API Enabled
example: Enabled if AWS > RDS > API Enabled
schema.default: Enabled if AWS > RDS > API Enabled

rdsPermissionsLockdownEngineTypes.title: Engine Types
rdsPermissionsLockdownEngineTypes.description: Configure whether lockdown policies are enabled to prohibit modification of Engine Types.
rdsPermissionsLockdownEngineTypes.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.engineTypes.items[0].value | length == 0 %} ['*'] {% endif %}{% for item in $.engineTypes.items[0].value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

rdsPermissionsLevels.title: Levels
rdsPermissionsLevels.description:
Define the permissions levels that can be used to grant access to an AWS account.
Permissions levels defined will appear in the UI to assign access to Turbot users.
This policy provides a default for `Permissions > Levels` in each service,
however you can explicitly override the setting for each service if desired
rdsPermissionsLevels.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.availableLevels.items[0].value | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.availableLevels.items[0].value %}- {{ item }}
{% endfor %}

rdsPermissionsLevelsModifiers.title: Modifiers
rdsPermissionsLevelsModifiers.description:
A map of AWS API to Turbot Permission Level used to customize Turbot's
standard permissions. You can add, remove or redefine the mapping of AWS
API operations to Turbot permissions levels here.

**Note:** Modifiers are cumulative - if you add a permission to the Metadata level,
it is also added to ReadOnly, Operator and Admin. Modifier policies set here apply ONLY to the AWS level

```
example:
  - "glacier:createvault": admin
  - "glacier:ListVaults": metadata
  - "s3:DeleteBucket": none
```

rdsPermissionsLevelsSubnetGroupAdministr.title: Subnet Group Administration
rdsPermissionsLevelsSubnetGroupAdministr.description: Determines which Turbot permissions level can manage Subnet Group Administration.

awsCompiledServicePermissions.title: @turbot/aws-rds
awsCompiledServicePermissions.description:
A calculated policy that Turbot uses to create a compiled
list of ALL permissions for AWS RDS that is used as input
to the control that manages the IAM stack.

awsCompiledLockdownStatements.title: @turbot/aws-rds
awsCompiledLockdownStatements.description:
A calculated policy that Turbot uses to create a compiled list of
ALL lockdown policy statements for AWS RDS that is used as input
to the stack that manages the Turbot IAM permissions objects.

awsLevelsCompiled.title: @turbot/aws-rds
awsLevelsCompiled.description:
A calculated policy that Turbot uses to create a compiled list of
ALL permissions for AWS RDS that is used as input to the stack
that manages the Turbot IAM permissions objects.

awsCompiledApiBoundary.title: @turbot/aws-rds
awsCompiledApiBoundary.description:
A read-only policy generated by Turbot that lists the APIs that
should be added to the turbot-managed (hard) boundary policy,
thereby enabling them to be assigned to users and roles.
This value will change depending on the value of the value of the
`AWS > RDS > Permissions > Lockdown > API Boundary` policy

rdsRegionsDefault.title: Regions
rdsRegionsDefault.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS RDS resources are supported for use.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and
'?' wildcard characters.

This policy is the default value for all AWS RDS resources' Regions policies.
rdsRegionsDefault.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions.value | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

rdsApprovedRegionsDefault.title: Approved Regions [Default]
rdsApprovedRegionsDefault.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS RDS resources are approved for use.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and
'?' wildcard characters.

This policy is the default value for all AWS RDS resources' Approved > Regions policies.
rdsApprovedRegionsDefault.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions.value | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

rdsStack.title: Stack
rdsStack.description:
Configure a custom stack on AWS, per the custom `Stack > Source`.

A Turbot `Stack` is a set of resources configured by Turbot, as specified
via Terraform source.  Stacks are responsible for the creation and deletion
of multiple resources. Once created, stack resources are responsible for
configuring themselves from the stack source via their `Configured` control.

rdsStackSource.description:

of multiple resources. Once created, stack resources are responsible for
configuring themselves from the stack source via their `Configured` control.

rdsTrustedAccounts.title: Trusted Accounts [Default]
rdsTrustedAccounts.description:
List of AWS Accounts that are trusted for access in the AWS RDS policy.

This policy is used by the Trusted Access
control to determine which members of type "account" are allowed

{% endfor %}{% endif %}

(**Note**: Setting CMDB to **"Skip"** will also pause these changes.)

subnetGroupConfigured.title: Configured
subnetGroupConfigured.description:
Determine how to configure this resource.

**Note**: If the resource is managed by another stack, then the Skip/Check/Enforce values here are ignored
and inherit from the stack that owns it

enum: Check: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)
Enforce: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)

subnetGroupConfiguredSource.title: Source
subnetGroupConfiguredSource.description: A HCL or JSON format Terraform configuration source used to configure this resource

subnetGroupConfiguredPrecedence.title: Claim Precedence
subnetGroupConfiguredPrecedence.description:
An ordered list of who is allowed to claim a resource.
A stack cannot claim a resource if it is already claimed by another
stack at a higher level of precedence.
subnetGroupConfiguredPrecedence.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultPrecedence | length == 0 %}[]{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultPrecedence %}- '{{ item }}'{% endfor %}{% endif %}

subnetGroupRegions.title: Regions
subnetGroupRegions.description:
A list of AWS regions in which AWS RDS subnet groups are supported for use.

Any subnet groups in a region not listed here will not be recorded in CMDB.

The expected format is an array of regions names. You may use the '*' and
'?' wildcard characters.
subnetGroupRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions.value | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

subnetGroupManagement.title: Management
subnetGroupManagement.description: If enabled, users with the RDS/Admin role can manage DB subnet groups.

subnetGroupTags.title: Tags
subnetGroupTags.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS RDS subnet group tags are not updated based on the `AWS > RDS > Subnet Group > Tags > *` policies.

The control ensure AWS RDS subnet group tags include tags defined in `AWS > RDS > Subnet Group > Tags > Template`.

Tags not defined in Subnet Group Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.

subnetGroupTagsTemplate.title: Template
subnetGroupTagsTemplate.description:
The template is used to generate the keys and values for AWS RDS subnet group.

Tags not defined in Subnet Group Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.
subnetGroupTagsTemplate.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultTags.value | length == 0 %} [] {%- elif $.defaultTags.value != undefined %}{{ $.defaultTags.value | dump | safe }}{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultTags.value %}- {{ item }}{% endfor %}{% endif %}

subnetGroupUsage.title: Usage
subnetGroupUsage.description:
Configure the number of AWS RDS subnet groups that can be used for this region and the current consumption against the limit.

You can configure the behavior of the control with this  `AWS > RDS > Subnet Group > Usage` policy.

subnetGroupUsageLimit.title: Limit
subnetGroupUsageLimit.description: Maximum number of items that can be created for this region.
